author: sky.cactus
content: It is unclear to me why the changes are slowing things down?  The impression I am getting (from the outside) is that Geth and Besu are done with implementation until there is agreement on what to do next, and no other client is actively implementing.

author: sky.cactus
content: I'm probably missing some insight into something.

author: sky.cactus
content: It sounds like we are all +1 on 2718 being a hard dependency for 1559, so I'll work on getting that integrated.  I'll do it as a separate PR against my PR just so people can review the two changesets separately, but we can merge them both around the same time if desired.

author: sky.cactus
content: It would be *nice* if we could include 2711 and 1559 at the same time.  If we include 1559 first, we'll have to create a new transaction type (and add complexity) for 2711 transactions once they land, and if we include 2711 first then we'll need to deprecate 2711 transactions once 1559 is included.

author: sky.cactus
content: If we do them both at the same time, we can avoid having to write and then deprecate code, which would be nice in the long run.

author: sky.cactus
content: Both at the same time *will* increase the engineering required to release *either* of them individually, but if we think there is a pretty good chance that 2711 and 1559 will land in the same hard fork time then I think we will overall save a notable amount of time, cognitive effort, and complexity by introducing them together.

author: sky.cactus
content: The irony of this request is not lost on me.  I am the biggest advocate against combining EIPs together.  The problem is that 1559 changes how *all* future transaction types work, and we have a bunch of EIPs open that introduce new transaction types (built on 2718).  The idea with 2711 is that it will become the future "base/normal/recommended" transaction type (superseding legacy transactions), and if we introduce 1559 separately then we'll have `legacy_transactions + 1559_transactions + 2711_transactions` instead of just `legacy_transactions + 1559/2711_transactions`.

author: .vbuterin
content: Yeah, there's definitely a "combinatorial complexity in EIPs" problem right now

author: .vbuterin
content: don't forget to throw account abstraction into the tensor product (or whatever kind of crazy multidimensional product this is)

author: sky.cactus
content: One could also imagine rolling up 2930 into this new monolithic transaction type.

author: sky.cactus
content: One can certainly imagine wanting to do a 1559 gas priced transaction that also has sponsorship (2711) and also provides an access list (2930).

author: sky.cactus
content: In fact, I would argue that once all 3 EIPs are out there, that is what most people *will* want.

author: .vbuterin
content: Maybe we should discuss this in the ACD today?

author: sky.cactus
content: The general argument here is: should we prefer a large set of transaction types because it makes trial and error of new transaction concepts easier, or should we prefer a small set (e.g., set of 1) of transaction types that everyone uses that have optional arguments?

author: sky.cactus
content: I think even if we do target a single monolithic transaction type then 2711 is still valuable because it gives us a mechanism for introducing the vNext transaction type along side vLegacy while we transition (e.g., via some kind of legacy transaction type tax) where we can eventually get people off of the old stuff.

author: sky.cactus
content: I'm going to wait to get more feedback before I proceed with updating the spec.  I started writing up a PR to make 1559 depend on 2711 and as I was doing so I realized "we should include the chainId like in 2718", then I started thinking about how it would be nice if sponsored transactions were also supported, and batch transactions, and expirations, and access lists...

author: sky.cactus
content: Barring some resolution in the ACD call, I'll probably include the `chainId` field in the new 1559 transaction type, but otherwise leave out 2711 and 2930 changes.  I can create a separate EIP that combines all 3 EIPs into a single new transaction type and we can *choose* to develop toward that if we want.  A bit more maintenance work for me, but it shouldn't be overly burdensome.

author: sky.cactus
content: I think perhaps the reason we aren't all in agreement on the path forward is because we don't agree on how "certain" we are about 1559 inclusion.  For example, I do not feel a need for the stress testing because I think that the 1559 change is sufficiently small/uninteresting and I don't feel a need for economic modeling because I'm confident in what has been done so far.

author: sky.cactus
content: I get the feeling that many people think 1559 is still a big question mark with no certainty of inclusion.

author: abdel.stark
content: Yeah i have the same feeling. Lot of uncertainty and probably also confusion about what it solves and what it does not solve

author: abdel.stark
